div.ab: Calandra larks & all birds taken from the nest & which have not had freedom are better, for these which are taken by net never sing so well. However, the savage ones give much pleasure with their chanting, but they ought be taken before Michaelmas, otherwise they scarcely live. A small impostume occurs on all on the fork of their tail, occasionally, which some call gaillardise, which makes them sick & sometimes makes them die, especially calandra larks. One knows when they are sad & do not sing. One must pierce it, not with a pin, but very gently by turning with the tip of quite pointy feather. The calandra lark does not want to be without river sand, & the gray is the best, a little coarse. It rubs itself & cleanses itself with it.

div.head: Grain of lead
div.ab: Take a pierced playing card, pierced with a pin or needle, folded on all four sides. Hold it with the end of a small split stick and, holding the said stick by theun bout other end, put your card three or 4 fingers away from the water that you will have put in a dish or similar vessel. Then pour your lead, which should not be too hot, into the card & continually tap on the stick that holds it. And thus your lead will turn into round grains. And pass it through a large sieve to separate the largest grain from the smallest. The larger one will reach 25 to 30 paces.

Those that are taken at Michaelmas are good for keeping, but those that are taken in March die, because they are starting to enter into love. Bénaris are fed oats all summer in order that they are fed without fattening, to be more appropriate for hunting & taking the others. Then, when one wants to fatten them for selling, one gives them millet. They sing at night. One needs to take them after mid-July until Michaelmas, for after that time that they have their young in this country, they go like the turtledoves. Siskins should also be taken from All Saints' Day until Christmas, for after they go to the mountains to brood.
